title: Microeconometrics: Methods and Applications
text:
Introduction
Some info about the context.

title: How to download the required data
text: In order to download the required data for the excersices in this virtual resource you will find the datasets for free acces in (I guess this will not be the definitive repository, but for the moment I will write mine) this GitHub repository.

title: Following Along with R
text: Some info about R and this chapter.

title: Introduction to R and Basic Tools Required for this book
text:
Here will be the introduction to R. Now an example of code visualization, this allows to write and execute code:

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data.frame(x=c(-3,3)), aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun=dnorm, args=list(mean=0, sd=1),
                geom="line", colour="red", size=1) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(-3,3), label = seq(-3,3)) +
  scale_y_continuous(expand= c(0,0)) +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 2, y = 0.3, parse = TRUE,
           label = "mu==0 ~ ',' ~ sigma == 1") +
  annotate("segment", x = 2, xend = 1.3, y = 0.27, yend = 0.2, colour = "black",
           size=0.6, arrow=arrow(length = unit(0.15, "cm"), type = "closed")) +
  labs(x = "x", y= "") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line.y = element_blank(),
        axis.ticks.y = element_blank())

Warning: Using `size` aesthetic for lines was deprecated in ggplot2 3.4.0.
â„¹ Please use `linewidth` instead.

title: Details required for Chapter 2
text:
Here will be the introduction to R. Now an example of code visualization, this allows to write and execute code:

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data.frame(x=c(-3,3)), aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun=dnorm, args=list(mean=0, sd=1),
                geom="line", colour="red", size=1) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(-3,3), label = seq(-3,3)) +
  scale_y_continuous(expand= c(0,0)) +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 2, y = 0.3, parse = TRUE,
           label = "mu==0 ~ ',' ~ sigma == 1") +
  annotate("segment", x = 2, xend = 1.3, y = 0.27, yend = 0.2, colour = "black",
           size=0.6, arrow=arrow(length = unit(0.15, "cm"), type = "closed")) +
  labs(x = "x", y= "") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line.y = element_blank(),
        axis.ticks.y = element_blank())

title: Details required for Chapter 3
text:
Here will be the introduction to R. Now an example of code visualization, this allows to write and execute code:

library(ggplot2)
ggplot(data.frame(x=c(-3,3)), aes(x)) +
  stat_function(fun=dnorm, args=list(mean=0, sd=1),
                geom="line", colour="red", size=1) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(-3,3), label = seq(-3,3)) +
  scale_y_continuous(expand= c(0,0)) +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 2, y = 0.3, parse = TRUE,
           label = "mu==0 ~ ',' ~ sigma == 1") +
  annotate("segment", x = 2, xend = 1.3, y = 0.27, yend = 0.2, colour = "black",
           size=0.6, arrow=arrow(length = unit(0.15, "cm"), type = "closed")) +
  labs(x = "x", y= "") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line.y = element_blank(),
        axis.ticks.y = element_blank())

title: Following Along with Stata
text: Some info about Stata and this Chapter.

title: Introduction to Stata
text:
Here will be the introduction to Stata. Now an example of code visualization:

library(Statamarkdown)

Warning: package 'Statamarkdown' was built under R version 4.2.3


Stata found at C:/Program Files/Stata16/StataMP-64.exe


The 'stata' engine is ready to use.



clear all
set obs 10000
gen x = -3 + 6/(_N-1)*(_n - 1)
gen y = normalden(x)
line y x

number of observations (_N) was 0, now 10,000





Normal Density
